Django was the actual answer to our PHP problems, and I'm one of those who learned Python by learning Django

I started using python when first installed a Zope/Plone CMS.  So I asked what is under this and the answer was python.  After that I moved to web development using a lot of non Django frameworks:  Nevow/twisted, turbogears1 and 2, pylons, flask.  Also for GUI desktop cross-platform I use python a lot ( wxpython ).

@muraii just as @davidpaccoud says, Django makes it pretty easy to learn Python along the way.  At first it can be a little difficult to understand what is Django magic and what is pure Python, but it all makes sense after enough tinkering.  I mostly just learned the basics of Python and Django at the same time from the official Django tutorial and various pluggable apps.  Then I started trying to make stuff with Python that didn't require Django (shell scripts and the like).

@varikin Slow compared to what?

@malero There are cases where Java (the main language I use a work) blows Python out of the water. Really, it is the JVM that blows CPython out of the water. The JIT is the JVM is amazing. Threading in the JVM is much better than the GIL approach. Really, Jython then has those same advantages, but still, Jython can be slower than Java due to how the dynamic nature of Python is handled in Jython. There are cases where you need to really drop down to C for the speed you need. CPython (and PyPy) have made amazing strides in performance, but it isn't the fastest thing out there. But given all that, I would rather use a language where I can just get shit done. Most of the time, that is fast enough. If I need it faster, I will go from there.

I code in Python because I stopped worrying about my programs being slow. I embraced the whitespace. I stopped thinking about public vs private. I realized there are time procedural is better. I realized there are times object oriented is better. I realized I could mix procedural and object oriented.
